caption: Table 1: Herd Effect RateBmah% via Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast). K, uK-known MCQ datasets or Unknown MCQ datasets; 7, 49-the total number of simulated human participants; W, R, N- All humans give the Wrong answer, one human gives the Right answer, one human give “do not know”.
description: This table presents the results of the Herd Effect experiment, showing the percentage of times each of seven different LLMs exhibited herd behavior under various conditions (different numbers of simulated human participants providing wrong, right, or 'don't know' answers, and using either known or unknown multiple-choice questions). The results are categorized by LLM model and experimental condition, showing the conformity rate of LLMs compared to humans in the Asch experiment.

caption: Table 2: Average RateBqa of remaining subset samples via Single-H-Single-A survey questions.
description: This table presents the average bias rates (RateBqa) for several cognitive biases across different LLM models.  RateBqa is a metric measuring the tendency of an LLM agent to exhibit a specific cognitive bias in a Single-Human-Single-Agent (Single-H-Single-A) question-answering scenario. The biases evaluated are Ban Franklin, Confirmation, Halo, and Gambler effects.  The values represent the percentage of times the LLM agent exhibited the bias.

caption: Table 3: Rumor Chain RateBmah via 15 Agents. Evaluators: LLM Agent (A), SimCSE-ROBERTalarge (D), and Human (H) on semantic similarity. RateBmah[Len]- content length.
description: This table presents the results of a rumor chain experiment using 15 LLM agents.  Three different methods were used to evaluate the semantic similarity of the transmitted message to the original message: LLM agent evaluation, SimCSE-ROBERTalarge evaluation, and human evaluation.  The table also shows the change in message length (content contraction rate).  The experiment is part of the evaluation of the Rumor Chain Effect.

caption: Table 1: Herd Effect RateBmah% via Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast). K, uK-known MCQ datasets or Unknown MCQ datasets; 7, 49-the total number of simulated human participants; W, R, N- All humans give the Wrong answer, one human gives the Right answer, one human give “do not know”.
description: This table presents the results of the Herd Effect experiment using the Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast) communication mode. It shows the percentage of times LLM agents conformed to the majority opinion (herd effect) under different conditions.  The conditions vary in terms of whether the multiple-choice questions (MCQs) were known or unknown, and the number of simulated human participants providing incorrect (W), correct (R), or uncertain (N) answers. The table allows for a comparison of LLM agent behavior to human behavior in the Asch conformity experiment.

caption: Table 1: Herd Effect RateBmah% via Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast). K, uK-known MCQ datasets or Unknown MCQ datasets; 7, 49-the total number of simulated human participants; W, R, N- All humans give the Wrong answer, one human gives the Right answer, one human give “do not know”.
description: This table presents the results of the Herd Effect experiment using the Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast) communication mode. It shows the percentage of times LLM agents exhibited herd behavior (i.e., conforming to the majority) under various conditions. These conditions include using either known (K) or unknown (uK) multiple-choice questions (MCQ) and varying the number of simulated human participants who provided either all wrong answers (W), one right answer (R), or one "don't know" answer (N). The results are categorized by LLM model, providing a comparison of their susceptibility to herd influence across different scenarios.

caption: Table 1: Herd Effect Rate Bmah% via Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast). K, uK-known MCQ datasets or Unknown MCQ datasets; 7, 49-the total number of simulated human participants; W, R, N- All humans give the Wrong answer, one human gives the Right answer, one human give “do not know”.
description: This table presents the results of the Herd Effect experiment, which measured the tendency of LLM agents to conform to the choices of simulated human participants. The experiment used two types of multiple-choice questions: known questions (where the answer was known to the models) and unknown questions (where the answers were not known). The table shows the percentage of times each LLM agent conformed to the majority opinion, under different conditions (all humans gave the wrong answer, one human gave the right answer, one human gave a "don't know" answer). The results are compared for both known and unknown MCQ datasets and different numbers of simulated human participants.

caption: Table 1: Herd Effect Rate Bmah% via Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast). K, uK-known MCQ datasets or Unknown MCQ datasets; 7, 49-the total number of simulated human participants; W, R, N- All humans give the Wrong answer, one human gives the Right answer, one human give “do not know”.
description: This table presents the results of the Herd Effect experiment using the Multi-H-Single-A (Broadcast) communication mode. It shows the percentage of times the LLM agents exhibited the herd effect under various conditions (different numbers of simulated human participants giving either wrong, right, or "do not know" answers, using known or unknown MCQ datasets).  The results are compared to Asch's observation of 75% conformity among humans.
